The nonlinear transitions in the two feedbacks explored in this study demonstrate the pressing need for a better understanding of state-dependent processes in the Earth’s climate system, both those associated with the Arctic and beyond. This is important because triggering these and other planetary feedbacks might accelerate the pace of climate change
13, 69 and increase the risks of irreversible socio-economic losses
70 . The methodology introduced in this paper could be used to quantitatively assess the economic and climate policy implications of the other tipping elements in the Earth’s climate system, including the Greenland and West Antarctic ice sheets, Amazon rainforest, boreal forest, Sahel and ENSO
13 . Such assessments could provide a more complete understanding of the socio-economic risks from climate change that in turn can help guide policymakers towards prudent decisions on emissions reduction targets.
